As of December 1, 2020, there have been 13.4 million COVID positive cases in 43 the United States, leading to over 267,000 deaths. According to the CDC, New Jersey 44 ranks second in the US with 190 deaths/100,000 cases 1, 2 . The COVID-19 pandemic put 45 extraordinary pressure on the healthcare system of New Jersey, as hospitals diverted both 46 physical and human resources to meet rising critical care demands. Additionally, the 47 resources normally used to provide orthopaedic care were repurposed 3 . Despite the re-48 allocation of resources, patients with orthopaedic trauma continued to present to the 49 trauma bay 4 . 50 Historically, SSI rates described for "all-comer" orthopaedic trauma patients 51 range from 1.3%-15.6% 5-8 . The causative agent of COVID-19, SARS-CoV-2, has been 52 shown to be transmitted via respiratory secretions and may be spread during orthopaedic 53 procedures 9-12 . This raises concern for increased perioperative complications, especially 54 increased complication and morality rates in COVID positive hip fracture patients [13] [14] [15] . 55 Current literature has described individual hospital experiences in response to 56 COVID-19, safety protocols, and perioperative outcomes with isolated extremity 57 fractures. To the best of our knowledge, no study has evaluated the effectiveness of the 58 implemented safety measures for all comer orthopaedic trauma patients. In addition, no 59 study has evaluated 180-day outcomes. Moreover, there is a paucity of literature that 60 exists regarding the impact of COVID test type ordered and its relationship to the 61 associated hospital course. 62

The objective of this study was to compare two cohorts of patients, a COVID 63 group and non-COVID control group that presented during the same seasonal period two 64 J o u r n a l P r e -p r o o f years ago, to evaluate the effectiveness of safety measures taken in response to COVID-65 19 to elucidate potential risk factors for complications associated with traumatic 66 orthopaedic injuries and COVID-19. body_text.text: The protocol employed a rotating four-team system of residents that functioned 102

body_text.text: independently of one another. The teams transitioned every four days and had no contact 103 with other team members. Patient care transitions were conducted over videoconference 104 in separate rooms. 105
body_text.section: Safety Protocol and Efficiency Measures 98

body_text.text: Patients that required urgent or emergent surgery warranted COVID-19 testing 106 with one of three tests: Cepheid, DiaSorin, or SARS-Cov2-RNA ('RNA'). Due to 107 limitations in supplies, the DiaSorin and Cepheid tests were to be ordered for patients that 108 required social disposition for emergent bed management from the ED. The DiaSorin test 109 was to be ordered between 7am to 7pm and the Cepheid test was to be ordered the 110 remaining time. The SARS-Cov2-RNA could be ordered at any time. Outside of the 111 Cepheid test, sample runs were conducted in batches at designated time points throughout 112 the day. Urgent surgical intervention proceeded with the assumption that the patient may 113 be COVID+ and without requirement to wait for the test result. COVID-U or COVID+ 114 patients were placed in designated negative pressure ORs. All intubations and extubations 115
body_text.section: Safety Protocol and Efficiency Measures 98

body_text.text: were performed with the least number of personnel and maximal personal protective 116 equipment (PPE). Surgical site sterilization and draping was performed in usual sterile 117 fashion, which was consistent between the two cohorts. During the procedure, the 118 surgical staff wore maximal PPE. Following the OR, COVID status determined the 119 patient disposition and appropriate droplet and contract precautions were taken for 120 COVID+ patients. 121

body_text.text: When evaluating just SSI, we found an increased number of SSI in the 2018 270 cohort (11 (4.5%) vs. 5 (2.7%), respectively, p=0.03). Our SSI rates fall within the lower 271 end of the spectrum between 1.3%-15.6% for SSI rates described for all-comer 272 orthopaedic trauma patients 5-8 . One possible explanation for the lower perioperative 273 complications is that during the pandemic there was increased vigilance to safety, most 274 notable in the OR setting. For patients that were COVID+ and COVIDu, the circulator 275 would request supplies from the hallway in order to limit in-and-out traffic. Additionally, Additional studies have demonstrated reduction of SSIs with less OR traffic 10, 21, 22 . 280

body_text.text: Limitations of this study include its retrospective design. To account for the 291 retrospective design, we compared the patients treated during the pandemic to cohort of 292 patients from the same seasonal period prior to the pandemic. body_text.text: However, we present two large cohorts of patients with 180-day perioperative findings 298 that demonstrate overall patient perioperative complications were not significantly 299 increased during the COVID-19 pandemic. Lastly, long-term outcomes are not available 300 at this time and it is possible for mortality and complication rates to increase. However, 301 we have offered the longest possible outcome study to date. 302
body_text.section: al. and Lebrun et al. who both reported an increased complication and mortality rate in 264

body_text.text: Nevertheless, this study has many strengths. To the best of our knowledge, we are 303 the first study to report results on all presenting orthopaedic trauma outcomes compared 304 to a similar cohort of non-COVID patients 13, 14, 23 . We report 180-day post-operative data, 305 which is the longest to date. In addition, this is the first study to analyze operational 306 efficiency during the pandemic in relation to COVID test type ordered. Furthermore, no 307 prior studies evaluated the cost analysis of differing COVID tests. 308
body_text.section: al. and Lebrun et al. who both reported an increased complication and mortality rate in 264
